reviewText: Great selection of movies & wonderful clarity on all the movies. I was delighted that each movie was on it's own individual DVD disc, but the packaging of the DVD discs is shameful! The four DVDs are literally stacked on top of each other, with no protection in between them. If you buy this product, please be very careful when you first remove them from the original packaging. I transferred mine into separate DVD disc cases to protect them from any scratches or damage.Jezebel - 1938Dark Victory - 1939Now, Voyager - 1942 (My favorite!)Old Acquaintance - 1943
summary: TCM Greatest Classic Legends Film Collection - Bette Davis

reviewText: Warners unveils their latest entries in the TCM Greatest Classic Films Collection.  Whilst NOW VOYAGER has previously been covered in theTCM Greatest Classic Films Collection: Romance (Splendor in the Grass / Love in the Afternoon / Mogambo / Now Voyager); the other three titles are must-own Bette Davis vehicles, and when bought together in this package are cheaper than the individual discs.NOW VOYAGER - Davis dazzles as Charlotte Vale, a miserable young spinster driven to the brink of a nervous breakdown by her shrewish mother (Dame Gladys Cooper in a masterful performance); but saved by a caring psychiatrist and a chance for love.  Special Features: music scoring sessions.DARK VICTORY - In the ultimate portrait of courage under fire, Davis is New England heiress Judith Traherne, faced with an incurable brain cancer that will eventually rob her of her sight.  Special Features:  new featurette "1939: Tough Competition for Dark Victory", audio commentary with James Ursini and Paul Clinton; and the trailer.OLD ACQUAINTANCE - Bette Davis slaps Miriam Hopkins silly in the signature scene from this ripe "women's picture".  Davis is Kit Marlowe, an author who willingly shuns fame and glory for the prestige of her work, whilst Hopkins is her antithesis, glamorous romance novelist Millie Drake, intent on destroying Kit's happiness when it happens to also involve Millie's husband and child!  Special Features:  audio commentary with Boze Hadleigh and director Vincent Sherman; and the trailer.JEZEBEL - When Scarlett O'Hara proved impossible, Bette Davis played her own wilful Southern belle to Oscar-winning effect in this splendid re-working of Owen Davis' play.  Even in black-and-white, the "red dress" ball scene sets the screen ablaze, as Julie (Davis) attempts to seduce her beau, Pres (Henry Fonda) into marrying her.  From a Yellow Fever outbreak to countless hoopskirted costumes, this sordid saga of the South has it all!  Special Features:  audio commentary with Jeanine Basinger, new featurette "Jezebel: Legend of the South", vintage musical short "Melody Masters: Jimmy Dorsey and His Orchestra", classic cartoon "The Mice Will Play"; and the trailer.
summary: yet another "Now Voyager" release, but still a good BETTE for Davis fans
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a great addition to your vintage movie collection and a wonderful addition to your Bette Davis film library.Now, Voyager was my favorite of the collection primarily due to the transformation of Charlotte Vale (played by Bette Davis).  There were no over the top gags (think modern fat suits) but subtle differences and changes.  When I first saw Ms. Davis in character I did not recognize her.  She was well masked behind things such as an outdated hairstyle, glasses and bushy eyebrows.  Rather than bulk her up with a fat suit she had just enough padding to make her "soft", fat by the standards of the day.  Ms. Davis' portrayal of Charlotte did not rely on makeup and costume alone.  She implemented nervous tendencies as a woman undone by years of heavy handed and demeaning control by her mother would cause.  After being under a doctor's care, she takes a cruise.  On the first port of call she is unpopular but by her return home she is the darling of the ship.  Although there are many events between those two stops there is little evidence as to why she so suddenly became so popular.  Her return home is a challenge that you are not sure she is up to and you really do sit on the edge of your seat, holding your breath to see if she will be bullied by her mother.  There is much more after her return home and it plays out well but the best of the movie is over after she deals with her mother.Dark Victory was just as pleasant to watch but the lead characters Judith Traherne played by Bette Davis and Dr. Frederick Steele played by George Brent seem to fall in love with each other a little too quickly, a little too easily.  Perhaps the details ended up on the cutting room floor.  If you like to catch mistakes caused by splicing various cuts together, pay attention to when Judith carries a tray of lunch out to Dr. Steele's office.  The contents going out and coming in are different and the tray is facing a different direction and when she comes back into the kitchen they are back to their original state.  NOTE:  Henry Travers a/k/a Clarence the angel from It's a Wonderful Life appears as Dr. Parsons.Old Acquaintance makes me want to scratch out Millie's eyes.  Miriam Hopkins plays Millie and this movie challenges me to buy more of her work to see her range and ability.  In the beginning of the movie Millie is a happily married housewife but very insecure and petty while Kit, played by Ms. Davis, is a successful, independent woman.  The two are best friends and when Kit comes to visit, Millie becomes jealous and decides to pursue the same career as Kit.  Her move to success is quickly established in order to push the plot along.  The point of focus is "Can a woman have it all - wife, family and career?"  This movie says no and is a bit dated.  It is however progressive for its day in that Kit walks around in a pajama top with no bottoms and Millie is shocked at the sight.  Later Kit dates a man 10 years younger than her, another progressive move.  Eventually he proposes.  You will have to see the movie to find out what happens.Jezebel came out a year before Gone With the Wind but the lead characters could be cut from the same cloth.  Ms. Davis plays Julie a woman just as headstrong and conniving as Scarlett O'Hara.  The big difference is that the length of Gone With the Wind gives more time for character development whereas Jezebel has to get to the point.  Ms. Davis won the Oscar for this movie and she deserved it.  I bought this collection for Jezebel but Now, Voyager dethroned it as my new favorite Bette Davis movie.

reviewText: Undoubtedly, this is an excellent collection of Bette Davis films. Each film comes in its individual discs, and in each Bette Davis performs headstrong independent women. Each film is also in pristine condition and they are all in black and white. My favorites here are Jezebel (1938) and Now, Voyager (1942). Personally, Dark Victory and Old Acquaintance don't draw a lot of enthusiasm, but that doesn't mean that these films are bad at all. Each one of her films presents great examples of her performances and compelling stories.In Jezebel, Davis pairs with Henry Fonda and George Brent in an antebellum drama where social conventions are challenged by the heroine, Julie Marsden (Davis), and later shattered by yellow fever. It is directed by William Wyler. In Now, Voyager she has a romance with Paul Henreid while on a cruise through South America. It is also about personal transformation for Charlotte Vale (Davis), where she starts as a secluded spinstress (literallly), and becomes a headstrong, independent woman who can also transform the lives of others. The romance may seem dated, but I find it delightful to watch. Specially, I enjoy listening to the romantic exchanges between Davies and Henreid with Max Steiner's soundtrack in the background. In Dark Victory, Bette Davis plays Judith Traherne, another headstrong lead who must face terminal illness, a tumor in the head. George Brent plays her doctor (with whom she marries) and Humphry Bogart, a stablehand who is in love with her. Although it might be considered a tear-jerker, it's still an important Bette Davis film. Old Acquaintance, the only comedy in the group, has Bette Davis play a successful writer who gets critical acclaim but doesn't sell well rival an old friend of hers who writes bestsellers, but doesn't get much critical approval. This may be the least interesting of the group, but the film is enjoyable, and Davis still delivers.I think that regardless of preferences for specific Bette Davis movies, film lovers will be satisfied by this collection.

reviewText: I went to buy "Now, Voyager" for my niece and was thrilled to find this collection of some of my favorite Bette Davis' movies, but also some of Bette's as well. It turned out to be a great gift. The movies are superb - Now Voyager has Bette as the ugly duckling turned into a lovely woman, with all the famous lines. Dark Victory with supporting actors Humphrey Bogart and Ronald Reagan. Jezebel is Bette's version of Scarlet O'Hara and won her an Oscar for Best Actress. And  Old Acquaintance has Bette and Miriam Hopkins feuding all the way through it. This is an outstanding buy from Amazon and I would recommend it to any Bette Davis fan and classic movie fan.

reviewText: Nothing says enough about Bette Davis.  Once you've seen one of her performances, you want to see them all.  She shines in each and every role, brings it to life and gets you to look through her eyes, reminding me of the Kim Carnes song, "Betty Davis Eyes".  Her femme fatale roles were dynamite.  Her drab characters made you pity the poor opressed woman and her struggles.  Her heroines were truly selfless in their wish to serve others.  No movie collection would be complete without her.
summary: A True Craftswoman at her best
